context.p: A linear trend line is the best fit straight line that is used for simple linear data sets. This trend line is mostly used to display a regular increase or decrease.

The comparison of the trend line is: y = a*x + b
a = slope (gradient)
b = y-intercept ( the point at which the line crosses the y-axis)
In the following example you explore the sales of the number of washing machines by a certain company for eight consecutive years.

step.cmd: Open the practice file and select worksheet Linear.
Select at Trendline Options: Linear. Let equation and R-squared value be displayed in the chart.
Change the chart title in Sales washing machines.
Add Axis titles and change title Y-axis in Number and title X-axis in Year.
Drag in the chart the equation to an empty place.

result.p: R2 = 0.9736 which means that the trend line fits the data very well.
